application.name: grid
application.brief: Add a grid to the input image.
application.description:
Superimpose a grid on an input image using input from the user. The grid can defined in terms of latitude and longitude, or simply lines and samples. For example, if you wanted to draw a grid that has an intersection at line 23, sample 17, with vertical lines every 30 pixels and horizontal lines every 40 pixels, your parameters would be: BASELINE = 23, BASESAMPLE = 17, SINC = 30, and LINC = 40.
If you wanted to draw a grid on a map projection that was based on latitude and longitude, GROUND would be selected instead. And suppose you wanted the grid to have an intersection at LAT 50, LON 60, with lines drawn every two and a half degrees latitude and every three degrees longitude. Your parameters would be: BASELAT = 50, BASELON = 60, LATINC = 2.5, and LONINC = 3.

history.change: Fixed problems with mapping outside of the projection space and with 0lat/0lon boundaries.
Added more line options, to change output to be HRS, LRS, NULL, or a DN.

Bug fixes for projections that use PositiveWest or Planetographic coordinate systems. The BASELAT and BASELON parameters are now expected to be in the units of the projection (if your cube has a planetographic latitude system, and baselat=50, then there will be a line at the planetographic latitude of 50).

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.description: Use this parameter to select the input file.

parameter.name: TO
parameter.description: This file will contain the grid.

parameter.name: MODE
parameter.description: This allows the user to decide which grid option to use.

option.brief: Add a grid in terms of lines and samples
option.description: A grid will be inserted into the image with spacing and position defined in terms of lines and samples.

option.brief: Add a grid in terms of lat/lon coordinates
option.description: A grid will be inserted into the image with spacing and position defined in terms of latitude and longitude.

parameter.name: TICKS
parameter.description: Draw ticks at lat, lon line intersections instead of lines

parameter.name: OUTLINE
parameter.description: This will draw grid lines at the very edges of the image

parameter.name: BASELINE
parameter.description: Starting line of grid. This, along with BASESAMPLE will give the program a starting point to draw the grid with.

parameter.name: BASESAMPLE
parameter.description: Starting sample of grid. This, along with BASELINE will give the program a starting point to draw the grid with.

parameter.name: LINC
parameter.description: This defines the number of lines between gridlines

parameter.name: SINC
parameter.description: This defines the number of samples between gridlines

parameter.name: BASELAT
parameter.description: This is a latitude line the grid will lie on. If it is not in the image, then it is a latitude line the grid would lie on if the image were larger. This is not a minimum latitude for the grid. If the image is projected, then this should be in the same units of the projection (for example, if your cube has a planetographic projection then this parameter will be interpretted as planetographic).

parameter.name: BASELON
parameter.description: This is a longitude line the grid will lie on. If it is not in the image, then it is a longitude line the grid would lie on if the image were larger. This is not a minimum longitude for the grid. If this image is projected, then this should be in the same units of the projection (for example, if your cube is projected in postive west then this longitude will be interpretted as a positive west longitude).

parameter.name: LATINC
parameter.description: This defines the latitudinal spacing between gridlines

parameter.name: LONINC
parameter.description: This defines the longitudinal spacing between gridlines

parameter.name: LINEWIDTH
parameter.description: This defines the thickness of grid lines in pixels.

parameter.name: LINEVALUE
parameter.description: This options allows for any DN value, or any of three special pixel values to be choosen as the line value.

option.description: Use the special pixel value HRS (High Representation Saturation) as the line value. This may vary with bittype used.
Use the special pixel value LRS (Low Representation Saturation) as the line value. This may vary with bittype used.
Use the special pixel value NULL as the line value. This may vary with bittype used.
Use the DN value specified in the DNVALUE parameter. It is a good idea to run the application stats on a cube before selecting a DN value.

parameter.name: DNVALUE
parameter.description: This is the DN value to be used as the value of the line. To pick an appropriate value, run the application stats first and use max or min.

parameter.name: DIAGONALTICKS
parameter.description: Instead of drawing the tick marks vertically and horizonally, creating a '+', draw the tick marks diagonally creating an 'x'

parameter.name: TICKSIZE
parameter.description: This defines the width and height (which are always equal) of the tick marks in pixels.
